results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response: To calculate the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets, the Group uses valuation techniques. The Group’s financial instruments that are not traded in active markets are measured at fair value using valuation techniques that are based on observable market data.
results.csv_string_response:
3.4 Valuation of interest rate swaps (including currency swaps) The table below analyses the Group’s financial instruments carried at fair value as at 31 December 2019 by level of the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. Such inputs are categorised into three levels within a fair value hierarchy as follows:
Quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (level 1);
Inputs other than quoted prices included within level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly (that is, as prices) or indirectly (that is, derived from prices) (level 2); and
Inputs for the asset or liability that are not based on observable market data (that is, unobservable inputs) (level 3).
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in an active market is determined by using valuation techniques. These valuation techniques maximise the use of observable market data where it is available and rely as little as possible on entity specific estimates. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.
If one or more of the significant inputs are not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3
results.json_rows_response: The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined by using valuation techniques.

results.question: How does a non-employee director receive his/her restricted stock unit award or option grant?
gold_answer: on the date of his or her initial appointment to the Board of Directors equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant
results.markdown_table_response: Non-employee directors receive their annual restricted stock unit award or option grant as a restricted stock unit award or option grant at the time of their initial appointment to the Board of Directors. The non-employee director’s pro-rata share of the annual grant is calculated by dividing the annual grant amount by the number of restricted stock units outstanding on the date of the annual grant and multiplying the result by the number of restricted stock units outstanding at the time of the annual grant.

The amount of the grant is equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant. The pro-rated amount is equal to the number of shares subject to the grant times the number of shares subject to the grant times the number of annual grants. The pro-rated amount of the annual grant is equal to the number of shares subject to the grant times the number of shares subject to the annual grant.

The Group has applied the new standard on 1 July 2018 using a simplified approach for measuring expected credit losses relating to trade receivables using a lifetime expected loss allowance.
To measure the expected credit losses, trade receivables are grouped based on region and ageing. Customers with heightened credit risk are provided for specifically based on historical default rates and forward looking information. The application of the standard did not result in any significant impact on the measurement of the allowance for doubtful debtors.
Collectability of trade receivables is reviewed on an ongoing basis. Debts which are known to be uncollectable are written off by reducing the carrying amount directly. A provision for impairment of trade receivables is raised when there is objective evidence that the Group will not be able to collect all amounts due according to the original terms of the receivables. Significant financial difficulties of the debtor, probability that the debtor will enter bankruptcy or financial reorganisation and default or delinquency in payments (more than 60 days overdue) are considered indicators that the trade receivable may be impaired. results.question: When is revenue recognized?
gold_answer: Revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer.
results.markdown_table_response: Data:
results.csv_string_response: The Company’s total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2019 will be recorded as follows:
results.json_rows_response: For the Year Ended December 31, 2019, Revenue is recognized when, or as, performance obligations under terms of a contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer. Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for transferring services to a customer (“transaction price”). The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. Revenue is recognized as revenue when, or as, the Company expects to receive the consideration. The Company’s license agreements and collaboration agreements contain a single performance obligation. The Company will recognize revenue when, or as, the Company expects to receive the consideration.

Revenue from the license agreements with customers is recognized when performance obligations under terms of the contract are satisfied, which occurs when control of the promised service is transferred to a customer. Revenue is measured as the amount of consideration the Company expects to receive in exchange for transferring services to a customer (“transaction price”). The Company will then recognize as revenue the amount of the transaction price that is allocated to the respective performance obligation when, or as, the performance obligation is satisfied. When determining the transaction price of the contract, an adjustment is made if payment from a customer occurs either significantly before or significantly after performance, resulting in a significant financing component. None of the Company’s licenses and collaboration agreements contained a significant financing component at either December 31, 2019 or 2018.

• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, coverage and signal quality, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology

• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

results.question: What is the average annual operating income in 2018 and 2019?
results.markdown_table_response: Average annual operating income in 2018 and 2019 was $77.2 million and $110.5 million, respectively. The increase in operating income between 2018 and 2019 was primarily driven by the increase in margins on work on development projects in New York, Boston, the San Francisco Bay Area and Brisbane. The increase in operating income was partially offset by lower margins on work on development projects in London and the negative impact of foreign currency exchange rates. CTS’s average annual operating income increased by $2.3 million as a result of the adoption of the new revenue recognition standard.

results.question: How much did net sales change between 2017 and 2018?
results.markdown_table_response: Net sales of $182,228 in fiscal year 2017 increased $19.7 million to $202,977 in fiscal year 2018.
results.csv_string_response: Net sales increased $19.7 million, or 10.8%, from $182.2 million in 2017 to $202.0 million in 2018.
results.json_rows_response: Net sales increased $19.7 million, or 10.8%, to $202.0 million in fiscal year 2018. The increase was primarily driven by an increase in net sales in the distributor channel across all the APAC and EMEA regions of $13.7 million, a $3.3 million increase in net sales in the OEM channel of the EMEA region and a $4.2 million increase in the EMS channel across the Americas, EMEA, and APAC regions. These increases were partially offset by a decrease in net sales of $1.2 million in the OEM channel across the Americas, APAC, and JPKO regions. In addition, there was a favorable impact of $7.6 million from foreign currency exchange primarily due to the change in the value of the Euro compared to the U.S. dollar.

results.question: How much did segment operating income change between 2017 and 2018?
results.markdown_table_response: Fiscal year 2018 operating income increased $12.7 million, or 6.1%, from 2017 operating income of $9.0 million. The increase was primarily attributable to an increase in net sales of $4.3 million, which was partially offset by a $3.6 million decrease in restructuring charges.
results.csv_string_response: The segment operating income of our Film and Electrolytic reportable segment in fiscal year 2018 increased $12.7 million, or 4.4%, from $9.0 million in fiscal year 2017. The increase was primarily attributable to an $11.7 million improvement in (gain) loss on the write down and disposal of long-lived assets, as well as the benefit of completed restructuring activities. The improvement was also attributed to a $4.3 million increase in gross margin driven by higher net sales, as well as the benefit of completed restructuring activities.
